cmd/phase/render.go.message: this removes support for rendering all documents

To clarify, this removes support for rendering all documents *easily*, this change allows a list of arguments so that you can render N phases, but I think a small enhancement to just render all documents or all documents that apply to a composite would be useful.  It does not have to be done in this patch, but it is an opportunity for a future enhancement.

Problem with multiphase rendering:
1. different phases may contain same documents (same group,version,kind and name) which is not allowed by kustomize (kustomize build raises an error in such cases)
2. different phases have different entry points (i.e. directories with kustomization.yaml) multiple sources of documents are not supported by airshipctl document module and

That being said user may still want to render all documents. Unfortunately phases approach is not fully designed  in terms of phase representation (dir vs kustomize resource with dir pointer). Therefore we can not get list of phases. Once 'phase list' feature is ready we can implement something like:
1. list all phases
2. get bundle for each phase
3. render each bundle from #2 to string (or byte array)
4. combine results from #3
5. apply filters to result
6. send filtered result to output (STDOUT)

This is a confusing release note because it doesn't supply enough information for users to be able to know if it applies to them.  My preference would be to omit the release note altogether because it is a minor fix to an error that did not cause jobs to fail and only occurred in some circumstances.  If we have too many release notes, people won't read them, so we try to keep bugfix release notes to major bugs that affect jobs.  However, if you've been getting questions about this and want to make sure that users know it's fixed, then I recommend rephrasing it to more accurately describe the circumstances under which it occurred.  Notably, it would only be seen when using an older kubectl or the openshift client as kubectl.  Perhaps something like:

In some cases (such as when an older version of kubectl is present on the executor, or the kubectl on the executor is from OpenShift), streaming logs from Kubernetes or OpenShift pods did not work.  The log streaming system has been corrected to work with a wider range of kubectl versions and error logging has been improved.

specs/victoria/approved/rbd-glance-multi.message: If there are multiple possible places from where nova-compute can use the image but none of them has the image, then nova ask glance to import the image to one of the accessible places, but which one? The first one or will it be configurable?

Thanks. I guess what confused me was the "examine all the current locations" that implied to me that nova has access to more than one places. 

I'm OK about the configuration of the backend name

Nova only has access to one of those places, i.e. the ceph cluster it's pointed at. So nova asks glance to copy it to that one. The only thing we need that we don't have today is for nova to know what the name of the glance backend is that represents its cluster. We'll need to allow that to be configurable in nova. Glance doesn't expose that through the stores API (afaict) but in the future it's possible that we could get them to add something so we could detect the backend name based on the fsid we already get from ceph. This is described in the deployer impact section, btw.
So by calling import with copy-image glance will start the copying. How nova will know when the import is finished?

Glance reports this in two different ways. First is through a task, but only admins can see that. The task also doesn't give us all that much information other than "preparing, copying, done".

The second way is that any user can see some additional properties on the glance image that indicate it is being copied to a given store, which also provides an indication of completion or failure. So, nova will initiate the copy and then keep checking on the image to see when it is done/failed. This is described in the deployer impact section regarding the poll interval tuning, but I can add some more text here if you want.

I think a simple sentence about the fact that nova will poll glance to see when the import is completed helps here to see the full picture. PS3 addition looks good to me.

I'm OK about the tuneables described later in the deployer section.
Configuration knobs like interval and timeout, I assume. Anything else?

I think it's just going to be those two, but that's kind of an implementation detail. I've thought about maybe trying to come up with some composite tunable that will attempt to scale back the polling based on image size or something, but I figure we can talk about that on the code patch. But, aside from the store name and some tunables that are context-sensitive to the code, that's it.
Sounds cool, I was just curious.

Note to self: the glance store name will be needed in order to call the glance import API I assume. Nova currently already knows something about the rbd store it's configured to use, but only via the configured ceph conf in images_rbd_ceph_conf, which has nothing to do with glance obviously.
Ack, sounds consistent with my understanding.

Nova only knows the rbd details and doesn't really know that glance knows about anything related to it until it is asked to boot an image, and sees that image has a location with the same fsid. So yeah, we need the glance store name because that's how glance's interface for copying images works. Glance can copy between more than just rbd stores, so just providing rbd details won't be enough.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: The /opt/backups directory can contain sensitive information and shouldn't be visible to non-root users. Backup/restore was working in the past with the current 0750 permissions - what changed to break this now?

I was wrong in the assumption that it wasn't mounted.

/opt/backups is mounted during bootstrap with 0755, after unlock it becomes 750.
Checked on 29-Feb-SX 5-Apr-DX.

There is a commit which changes the perms to 0750 during bootstrap.
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/724270/

puppet/2020-05-22-20-58-17_controller/puppet.log:2020-05-22T20:59:55.886 Debug: 2020-05-22 20:59:55 +0000 Exec[Change /opt/backups dir permissions](provider=posix): Executing 'chmod 0750 /opt/backups'
Thanks Dan - my vote would be to temporarily escalate /opt/backups permissions to 0751 during the restore.

Since 751 is not permanently desired, possible solutions: 
1) temporary escalate /opt/backups permissions to 0751 during restore.
2) temporary add postgres user root group.
3) Extract files needed by postrges user somewhere else. /tmp

Until recently, /opt/backups was not created during bootstrap, but during unlock. This allowed ansible restore code to create `{{ staging_dir }}/postgres` in a recursive manner enforcing execute permission on it(/opt/backups). Thus postgres user was able to read {{ staging_dir }}/postgres.
During unlock /opt/backups permissions were modified to default 750.

Also it becomes a mount point.
/dev/mapper/cgts--vg-backup--lv    20G   28M   19G   1% /opt/backups

Something in puppet changed, mounting it during bootstrap. Since /opt/backups exists, code to create `{{ staging_dir }}/postgres` will not enforce permissions on /opt/backups.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Please expand on this to explain when this error is seen and what you are doing to fix it.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/resto.message: So why is the code on line 320 that creates {{ staging_dir }}/postgres not sufficient?
+At a minimum the file permissions are enforced on a leaf node.

Code on line 336 doesn't allow folder traversal.
This issue was introduced by: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/724270/2/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/manifests/filesystem.pp 8-9 days ago.

The problem is that, when doing a bootstrap w/o the changes that introduced the issue, folder permission is 755 yet, after controller-0 unlock, folder permission change to 750 (!).

With the changes that introduces the issue folder permissions are 750 from the beginning and this breaks restore.

Thereseems to be an issue with the puppet mount library as it doesn't do what is supposed to (set the correct permissions for the mounts in the first place, not after restart through I don't even know what internal mechanism) that's why the chmod was needed in the first place.

The solution proposed here will set the permissions temporary, so that postgresql can restore its database. After controller-0 unlock permissions will return to 750.

(Dan, please correct me if I'm wrong here).

We can dig further on this issue but I don't believe it's worth the effort.

It looks to me on a normal install that the permissions on /opt/backups are 0750 and the ownership is root/root. So the code on line 336 to restore postgres as the postgres user is failing? Why was this working before and now is broken? What changed?
Modifying the permissions of /opt/backups to 0755 here is not the right solution. I assume we wanted /opt/backups to be 0750 so non-root users could not read the sensitive information stored in the backups.

Target of `file` module is {{ staging_dir }}/postgres. Seems permissions are enforced starting from first nonexisting file down to leaf node files. The behavior is not documented. /opt/backups exists because it is created by puppet.

This isn't going to be useful in the future. Please change to:
# User postgres needs access files in this folder during restore
# Permissions will be set back to 0750 when host is unlocked

magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernet.message: In this way, it seems we're also using the same version of the kube-apiserver. So could you please help me understand why do we need a separate script to install the kubectl?

relaying Bharat's comment to have the discussion in one place.

 > We should consider doing a similar thing after cluster upgrades to
 > ensure that the kubernetes client binary is replaced with the new
 > version too but if kubectl is only required for heat-container-agent
 > bootstrapping, ignore my comment.

kubectl is required (check [0]) and would break because it references /usr/local/bin explicitly. We either must change the absolute bath to just kubectl to be taken from $PATH or continue doing it with the current way and change only the agent as mentioned before. We can use the install kubectl script in the upgrade software deployment too.

An argument that intalling kubectl together with the update of kubelet container could be made, but has little ground since upgrades are only possible between releases that are not too far away one from another.

https://github.com/openstack/magnum/blob/master/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/upgrade-kubernetes.sh

For info:
This systemd unit is enabled here [0][1][2], which is ok in ordering.

1. This was in-place here to have the same functionality as the system containers which was coying to /usr/local/bin. /usr/local/bin is not mounted in the heat-agent and can't be mounted in the agents /usr/local/bin or /usr/bin because other files exist there. It should be in a non-standard path as proposed in this patch. It is probably ok to mount the host's /usr/local/bin to a non-standard path in the agent and add it to the PATH.

To make point 1., using this way to get kubectl would require either to change the heat-agent systemd unit to mount the host's /usr/local/bin, or change all references of kubectl to execute over ssh in the host's shell which would also need a valid kubeconfig on the host (my other patch fixed this).

2. This way of installing kubectl is more like a side effect of starting the agent. Which required that kubectl will always exists in the kube-apiserver image. We could use the kubelet systemd unit, yet a side effect executed on *every* restart of kubelet/kube-apiserver. With what is proposed in this patch we explicitly check if kubectl is set properly. (For info, the current state is use kubectl embedded in the agent which is 1.15.2 and hard to track kubectl version in the agent)

3. We have the same thing in two places. This patch fixes the duplication as well as the idea of changing how the heat-agent starts.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This should be an rfe, and discussed with drivers team.

In the RFE please write about the problem you want to solve with this API change. That's the possible benefit we need to balance with the disadvantages of a change like this, just a few for example:

* what if the port's MAC collides in the new network?
* what if the old and new networks have different MTUs?
* there are L2-only port use cases, how does the user of an L2-only port detect the network change?
* how does a neutron API user tell when the network change got  completed in the backend?

If your intent is to change the network of a port that's not yet used, what does prevent you to delete this port and create a new instead? If that's a limitation of the orchestration system you have, I don't think that should be worked around in neutron.

common/deploy-steps.j2.message: any reason not to use a module for this? Something like https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/sefcontext_module.html

Actually doesn't look like we used the module.

1) added as https://review.opendev.org/#/c/628191/
2) updated to create dir and then do it https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706449/
3) rewritten to drop the dir creation and make it look like this https://review.opendev.org/#/c/709576/

TBH, for recursive filesystem changes I would never use an ansible module as they tend to be terribly slow.  I'm not even sure we still need this as I think it was for a docker -> podman thing.

That being said this was an update/upgrade target so I think moving it to this spot is wrong. I think I just need to create a new play in the common deploy steps.

We did previously, it was changed at some point. Would have to dig through the historical context to find out. My assumption is that chcon -R is faster than using the modules. Similar to the file module being awful for recursion.

roles/build-wheels/files/wheel-build.sh.message:
Or actually, to still properly cover the old pattern this was previously designed around...

  's,.*Downloading.*[ /]\([^ /]*\.whl\)\([ #].*\|$\),\1,p'

This log line seems to be in flux: pip 19.2.3 looks like...

  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/43/84/23ed6a1796480a6f1a2d38f2802901d078266bda38388954d01d3f2e821d/pip-20.1.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (1.5MB)

...while pip 20.1.1 does...

  Downloading urllib3-1.25.9-py2.py3-none-any.whl (126 kB)

...so maybe we could future-proof it a bit more like:

's,.*Downloading.*[ /]\([^ /]*\.whl\)\([ #](.*)\)\?,\1,p'

That would match the original pattern as well as those emitted by 19.2.3 and 20.1.1, so may also match future entries better (or may not).

So throughout tempest, we use dict() for such methods AFAIK. Here are some examples:

1. https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/7ad6abd520cb8d3c2919409f28ab6f60611be29d/tempest/api/image/v2/admin/test_images.py#L48-L49

Yeah idk how it got extra indented, wasn't the same locally.

I would think adding a CONF.option with a generic default would be satisfactory for something like this.  

Also nit, just for consistency you can change 'dict(add='/version',...' to match the approach of passing dictionaries throughout the method, i.e. change to [{'add': '/version', 'value': image_version}].
Alternatively you could decorate the snapshot image, boot the second instance from it and then snapshot the instance one final time. I think this is more realistic tbh.
so insert the version here instead of above? can do

        # add version metadata to the snapshot image
        self.image_client.update_image(
            snapshot_image['id'], [dict(add='/version',
                                        value='8.0')])

or break it out onto another line:

        # add version metadata to the snapshot image
        self.image_client.update_image(
            snapshot_image['id'], [
                dict(add='/version', value='8.0')])

if these  configs are required by swift clients based deployments , please move them after line#371

The request to have those configurations to be set is from the functest team who is in charge of the CNTT referemce certification testing. Details is here: https://jira.opnfv.org/browse/AIRSHIP-40. I should note that CNTT certification testing is not dictating the values per se. The default values here is from a different system under test in CNTT, and also seems to be common values from searches online. But we are free to set to other values OSH deems to fit here. We can always override it in CNTT Airship deployment is needed.

test/functional/__init__.py.message:
Probably we should define storage_host as well?

That is because the s3 auth model is different from swift itself (s3 doesn't get the token from the auth uri before the request) so the mixture of use of auth_host might be complex for the testers. And it might be nice to set prefix like "s3_" to be intuitive that would never overwrite any storage url for SWIFT func testing.

...and storage_ssl...

I might even prefer something like storage_url, which would let you do something like

 storage_url = http://saio:8080

or

 storage_url = https://saio:4433

requirements.txt.message:
Thanks for taking care of this. Still, we should include PyMI instead of the legacy wmi lib.

PyMI is backwards compatible with wmi but is a complete rewrite of this library using a C Python extension, which is much more efficient.

For what is worth, os-win marks both libraries as dependencies in order to support older Windows Server versions (e.g. WS 2012) as some Hyper-V features were not accessible through the MI API, requiring the COM based WMI API (not the case here).

https://github.com/openstack/os-win/blob/master/requirements.txt#L16-L17

doc/source/operations/rook_migration.rst.message: I would suggest to change the file name from "root_migration" to "ceph_cluster_migration".
--> "how to step by step migrate the Ceph cluster, which was deployed as a part of StarlingX 3.0, to the containerized Ceph cluster deployed by Rook."

Let's make the background straightforward: "In StarlingX 3.0 or lower versions, Ceph as the backend storage cluster solution was deployed directly on the host platform. While, starting from 4.0, Ceph cluster will be containerized and managed by Rook, for the sake of operation and maintenance efficiency. Therefore, in the context of StarlingX upgrade from 3.0 to 4.0, we are here introducing a method to migrate the original Ceph cluster deployed by users at 3.0 provisioning stage to the newly containerized Ceph cluster at 4.0, while keeping user data (in OSDs) uncorrupted. "
-> "Ceph services, otherwise the migration procedure might be interfered due to the  continuous service restarting."
should separately AIO and multi-nodes system, the mon migration approach is a litter different.
if so, would you like to add prerequisites for multi-nodes only ?
this doc is only for multi-node
we should mention to remove native ceph backend in end.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Is it OK to be referencing this exec which is defined in openstack::horizon::reload without having a dependency? Don should comment on whether there is a better way to do this.
This should be using sm-restart-safe so there isnt a swact in case the user runs several http modifications in sucession.

I think Bart's point is that there's no inclusion here, so you're relying on the current sysinv implementation that also references openstack::lighttpd::runtime in order to define this exec. Without that inclusion, this exec does not exist, and this fails. Which means "platform::helm::runtime" is not a standalone class. You should probably try adding "include ::openstack::lighttpd::runtime" in this class, to explicitly define this dependency.

> Is it OK to be referencing this exec which is defined in
 > openstack::horizon::reload without having a dependency? Don should
 > comment on whether there is a better way to do this.

It is verified by testing that this is working properly. Also on line 31 there is an example where Exec['Stop lighttpd'] is referenced as a before relationship, and Exec['Stop lighttpd'] is declared in class openstack::horizon.
